title: Implementation of the Tram / Cycle Safety Action Plan agreed December 2016

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Between January 2015 and January 2017, Cycle Sheffield recorded over 380 crashes involving cyclists on tram tracks. As of today's date, there are 841 recorded crashes: an average of 7 recorded crashes per month between January 2015 and May 2024 (
https://www.cyclesheffield.org.uk/2017/0...
)
In December 2016 Sheffield City Council approved a Tram / Cycle Safety Action Plan.
This plan contained five specific action points, which I have listed below. I have numbered the list for ease of reference. I have followed each one with my questions:
1 - "By March 2017 design solutions at the top five worst accident sites"
a) Please provide a list of the top five worst accident sites.
b) Please provide copies of the agreed design solutions for these sites.
2 - "By June 2017 design solutions for the remaining top 20 sites. Agree a schedule of work for these solutions to be implemented in financial years 2017/18 and 2018/19"
a) Please provide a list of the remaining 15 sites.
b) Please provide copies of the agreed design solutions for these sites.
c) Please provide a copy of the agreed schedule for those solutions to be implemented.
3  - "Complete implementation of the top 5 sites by September 2017"
a) Please provide the actual dates when the these were implemented.
4 - "Develop in 2016/17 and pilot 2017/18 a cyclist/ tram-track solution for each type of tram/ carriageway interface (e.g. tram stops, tram track leaves road to left, to right etc.). Develop a plan for the deployment of these solutions and an on-going programme of works and ensure that these solutions are incorporated in all future Supertram infrastructure schemes."
a) Please provide a list of the types of tram/carriageway interface that were considered.
b) Please provide details of the sites where solutions were piloted.
c) Please provide the dates when these solutions were piloted.
d) Please provide copies of the evaluation of the pilot solutions.
e) Please provide a copy of the plan for the deployment of these solutions.
5 -" During financial years 2017/ 18 and 2018/ 19 implement solutions for the top 20 accident sites."
a) Please provide the actual dates when these were implemented.
For the avoidance of doubt, please note that the erection of warning notices stating "Tram Tracks - Wheels may slip or catch" was listed as an immediate interim measure prior to the implementation of more permanent solutions, and do not form part of any of the action points listed above.
Yours faithfully,
Rebecca Hammond

Dear Rebecca Hammond,
Thank you for your request for information relating to implementation of
the Tram / Cycle Safety Action Plan agreed December 2016 which we received
on 28/05/2024.
We apologise for the delay in responding.
Budgets to deliver significant active travel interventions come to us by
way of bids from the DfT via South Yorkshire Mayoral Combined Authority
(SYMCA). More information about the SYMCA can be found here [1]South
Yorkshire Mayoral Combined Authority - South Yorkshire MCA
(southyorkshire-ca.gov.uk)  We can only build what we have bid for using
this funding avenue (we cannot divert funding onto other projects). The
DfT set the criteria for said bids and for the last 5 or 6 years if not
more that criteria has focussed on boosting the economy – creating better
options for travel to reduce traffic and thus open up development sites.
In addition, providing better travel options enables the population to
travel to locations that may only be currently accessible by car.
In general, our approach has been to focus on improving parallel routes,
such as the University - Leavygreave - Portobello route which is now a
high-quality alternative route to West Street, rather than trying to make
changes on the sections of tram route, this means that we are avoiding the
risk more fully by passing Tram hotspots. We have ATF funding to review
the route from the city along Penistone Road which is parallel to Langsett
Road and improvements between City Centre – Kelham are currently being
delivered as part of the route.
We do however through what was known as the Local Transport Plan have a
discretionary budget, and a percentage of that is allocated to Road Safety
and that allocation is earmarked for those locations that are the worst
ranked for road safety.
We do wait on the results of the Ghent study (into infilling of tracks).
This may not prevent slipping but may prevent wheels getting stuck
[2]Cyclists get safer tram tracks in Ghent - Cities Today
(cities-today.com)
